;;纽约市市长埃里克·亚当斯 (Eric Adams) 在哥伦比亚波哥大访问哥伦比亚期间就达连峡的非正常迁徙情况发表声明2023 年 10 月 7 日。路透社/Luisa Gonzalez;
;

;周四，FBI 特工搜查了纽约市市长埃里克·亚当斯 (Eric Adams) 首席竞选筹款人布莱恩娜·萨格斯 (Brianna Suggs) 的住所，她受到公众询问据当地媒体报道，亚当斯周四前往华盛顿与美国政府官员举行会议，讨论该市寻求庇护者和其他新近抵达的移民的住房危机，但突然取消了这些会议以返回纽约约克。

;

;根据她在 LinkedIn 社交媒体网络上的个人资料，萨格斯自 2017 年以来一直为亚当斯工作，从亚当斯担任布鲁克林区长时开始在他的办公室实习。

;

;根据竞选财务披露，她为亚当斯在 2021 年成功竞选市长竞选活动筹集了 1,840 万美元，并为他的 2025 年连任竞选筹集了超过 270 万美元的捐款。

;

;萨格斯可以未能立即联系到置评。联邦调查局和亚当斯办公室的发言人没有回应置评请求。

;

;当被问及搜查时，亚当斯竞选团队的发言人分享了竞选顾问维托·皮塔的一份声明：“亚当斯市长没有作为本次调查的一部分，我们已联系。他始终以最高标准来开展这场活动。”

;

;联邦调查局发言人向《纽约时报》证实，他们正在萨格斯位于布鲁克林皇冠高地附近的家中开展“执法行动”。论文报道。 《泰晤士报》援引一位知情人士的话说，萨格斯受到了联邦调查局公共腐败小组特工的讯问。

;

;执法官员近几个月来调查了亚当斯的其他几名同伙。 7 月，曼哈顿地区检察官阿尔文·布拉格 (Alvin Bragg) 宣布起诉六人，称他们利用秸秆捐赠计划非法为亚当斯 2021 年竞选活动筹集公共配套资金。所有六名男子均表示无罪。

;

;亚当斯在起诉书中没有被指控有任何不当行为，他表示，他和他的竞选团队不了解或参与了所指控的计划。公开记录显示，亚当斯的 2025 年竞选活动迄今为止已向萨格斯的咨询公司 Suggs Solutions 支付了约 98,000 美元。

;

;在为亚当斯的竞选活动筹集捐款的同时，萨格斯还获得了代表其政府游说的报酬。据《纽约每日新闻》四月份报道，一位曼哈顿业主寻求延长其在市政府拥有的建筑内的购物中心的租约。

;;2023 年 11 月 2 日，巴勒斯坦人聚集在以色列袭击加沙地带中部布赖吉房屋的现场。 REUTERS/Mohammed Fayq Abu穆斯塔法;
;

;巴林周四表示，海湾国家驻以色列大使已回国，以色列驻麦纳麦大使“不久前”已离开该国，证实了议会早些时候发表的与;以色列与哈马斯冲突;平民伤亡人数不断上升;以及以色列对人口稠密的沿海飞地的封锁。

;

;政府声明并未证实经济联系正如议会早些时候所说，两国之间的航班已被切断，但表示两国之间的航班已暂停数周。

;

;声明没有澄清这是否意味着以色列大使已被驱逐。

;

; p>;

;以色列早些时候表示，没有收到任何此类行动的消息，并称其与巴林的关系“稳​​定”。

;

;在声明中，议会（一个在以色列境内没有权力的咨询机构）外交政策领域 - 表示此举“证实了巴林支持巴勒斯坦事业的历史性立场”。

;

;“国民议会确认以色列驻巴林王国大使已离开巴林和巴林王国巴林已决定巴林驻以色列大使返回，”议会在一份声明中表示。

;

;“还决定停止经济关系”，但没有明确是谁做出的决定.

;

;以色列外交部在一份声明中表示：“我们想澄清，尚未收到巴林政府和以色列政府关于遣返两国大使的通知或决定。以色列和巴林之间的关系稳定。”

;

;任何暂停外交和经济关系的行为如果得到证实，都将给以色列带来重大挫折。

;

;巴林是美国的所在地海军第五舰队是《亚伯拉罕协议》的签署国，该协议是以色列与多个阿拉伯国家于 2020 年签署的一系列正常化协议。

;

;华盛顿帮助促成了以色列与阿拉伯国家之间的此类协议，这是此类协议中的第一个自 1994 年以来，以色列一直希望这些协议最终能为与沙特阿拉伯的正常化协议铺平道路，沙特阿拉伯是一个在中东地区拥有巨大影响力的石油和穆斯林大国。但以色列与哈马斯的战争已经上个月，在沙特阿拉伯举行的一次投资会议上，巴林财政部长谢赫·萨勒曼·本·哈利法·阿勒哈利法在被问及有关该项目的问题时表示，继续搭建桥梁非常重要。亚伯拉罕协议。

;

;几天前，巴林工业和商务部长阿卜杜拉·本·阿德尔·法赫罗 (Abdulla bin Adel Fakhro) 在 10 月份在阿布扎比举行的一次会议上被问及与以色列的贸易和投资关系状况时拒绝发表评论。

;

;数十年之久的巴以冲突中的最新一场战争始于 10 月 7 日哈马斯武装分子突破边境。以色列称，他们杀害了 1,400 人，其中大部分是平民，并劫持了 200 多名人质。

;< p>;据加沙卫生当局称，以色列随后对拥有 230 万人口的巴勒斯坦小飞地进行轰炸，已造成至少 9,601 人死亡，其中包括 3,760 名儿童。

;

;巴林是海湾上的一个小岛，逊尼派穆斯林在此结盟沙特阿拉伯的哈利法王室统治着什叶派占多数的人口。

;

;分析人士表示，巴林与以色列和解的部分原因是对伊朗的共同恐惧。

;

;巴林的议会由代表委员会和由国王任命的 40 名舒拉委员会组成。

;;古巴外交部长布鲁诺·罗德里格斯于 2023 年 10 月 19 日在古巴哈瓦那举行的新闻发布会上发表讲话。 REUTERS/Carlos Carrillo/档案照片< /small>;
;

;联合国大会第 31 次呼吁美国终止对古巴长达数十年的贸易禁运，因为这个共产主义统治的岛屿正遭受最严重的苦难 ;几十年来经济危机;，粮食短缺，;燃料;和药品。

;

;这项不具约束力的决议获得了 187 个国家和地区的批准。只有美国和以色列反对，乌克兰投了弃权票。

;

;古巴外交部长布鲁诺·罗德里格斯在大会上发表讲话时表示，“封锁使古巴无法获得食品、药品以及技术和医疗设备。 “

;

;哈瓦那还被禁止向邻国美国出口，罗德里格斯说，这限制了其商品进入庞大市场的机会，仅 2022 年就给古巴造成了近 50 亿美元的损失。

;

;“封锁（禁运）构成种族灭绝罪”，罗德里格斯说。他说，美国的政策故意旨在加剧古巴人民的苦难，以迫使政府进行变革。

;

;贸易禁运是在菲德尔·卡斯特罗 1959 年革命之后实施的，尽管前总统唐纳德·特朗普加强了一些内容，但基本上没有变化。美国法律法规网络使金融交易以及古巴政府购买商品和服务变得复杂。

;

;美国外交官保罗·福姆斯比在反对该决议的简短讲话中表示，禁运旨在促进“古巴的人权和基本自由”，并且美国出于人道主义目的做出了例外。

;

;“美国仍然是古巴人民人道主义物资的重要来源，也是古巴的主要贸易伙伴之一， ”这位外交官说道。

;

;他指出，美国去年向古巴出售了价值 2.95 亿美元的农产品。

;

;古巴和美国之间长期存在的争端几乎没有迹象表明尽管在美国总统乔·拜登的领导下，双方表现出了一些温和的善意姿态，但两国关系仍处于缓和状态。

;

;拜登已采取小步骤放松对古巴的限制，加强领事服务，但在废除特朗普的制裁方面几乎没有采取任何行动。

; p>; Fri, 03 Nov 2023 02:25:03 +0800 Scientists observe chimpanzees using human-like warfare tactichttps://reuters.com/article/science-chimpanzees/scientists-observe-chimpanzees-using-human-like-warfare-tactic-idUSKBN31X1T2

;;2023-11-02T18:10:33Z;
;

;在危险地区边界，一支约30人的边境巡逻队爬上石山进行巡逻侦察。小队察觉到敌人的声音距离太近，不太舒服，于是撤退了。没有理由冒着与你不利的风险进行战斗。

;

;这种情况在人类战争史上已经出现过无数次。但在这种情况下，它涉及的不是人，而是;黑猩猩; 位于科特迪瓦西南部的泰国家公园，这是西非最大的雨林保护区。

;

;研究人员周四表示，他们在每天观察两个邻近社区的同时，记录了战争局势中高地地形的战术使用研究发现，在泰国家公园对野生西部黑猩猩进行了三年的调查。

;

;研究发现，在山顶侦察过程中获得的信息决定了黑猩猩是否会侵入敌方领地，当存在风险时，这些猿类似乎更倾向于这样做。对抗性较低。研究人员表示，这项研究首次记录了我们物种最亲近的现存亲属对这种古老的人类军事策略的使用。

;

;“它显示了复杂的认知和合作技能，可以预测何时何地。剑桥大学生物人类学家 Sylvain Lemoine 说道，他是发表在《;公共科学图书馆生物学;。

;

;群体间暴力在黑猩猩中普遍存在，勒莫万说。在重叠的边境地区偶尔会发生小冲突。

;

;“黑猩猩争夺空间，其中包括食物资源。大的领土是有益的，因为它减少了群体内的竞争，并且在更大的领土上雌性繁殖率会提高，”Lemoine

;

;本研究追踪的两个相邻群体的规模相当，在 40 至 45 只个体之间，其中大约有 5 至 6 名成年男性和 10 至 13 名成年女性，其余为青少年、少年和婴儿。 。研究人员表示，雄性总是比雌性占主导地位。

;

;“黑猩猩的领地意识极强。它们定期进行边境巡逻，个体以非常协调和有凝聚力的方式在领地外围漫游，”莱莫万说.

;

;“他们进行暴力、危险和有压力的群体间遭遇。群体间遭遇可以是远距离的声音交流、视觉接触或身体接触，包括打架、咬伤和追逐。杀戮是很常见，受害者可能来自各个年龄段。”Lemoine 补充道。

;

;爬山并不一定能改善对敌对社区成员的视觉检测，而是提供改善的声学条件，通过声音检测对手。

;

; p>;

;“山顶上覆盖着植被，不提供良好的观察点，”勒莫万说。

;

;在边境山顶上时，黑猩猩通常不会大声进食或觅食，而是休息并倾听。

;

;如果竞争对手的黑猩猩距离较远，它们下山后更有可能进入危险区域。当对手距对手约十分之三英里（500 米）时，此类入侵发生的概率约为 40%；当对手距对手约十分之六英里（1 公里）时，此类侵入发生的概率为 50%；当对手距对手约 1.9 英里时，此类侵入的概率为 60%。数英里（3 公里）之外。

;

;黑猩猩和关系密切的倭黑猩猩是基因上最接近人类的物种，与人类拥有约 98.8% 的 DNA 相同。根据;研究;于六月发表。

;

;研究黑猩猩的行为可以让我们深入了解我们自己的物种。

;

;“我们可以更好地了解我们来自哪里以及是什么造就了我们“我们人类。我们可以更好地了解人类和黑猩猩最后的共同祖先中存在哪些行为和适应性，并更好地了解古代人类物种的社会性和行为，”莱莫万说，他指的是地球上灭绝的物种。人类血统。

;

;“它还告诉我们，我们与我们现存的最亲近的亲戚有什么共同点，我们与野生动物有多么相似，以及我们与我们的表兄弟只是程度不同，而不是性质不同，”添加了 Lemoine。

;;Hundreds of people were killed or buried under rubble after two Israeli strikes on Gaza's largest refugee camp, Hamas said on Thursday (2 November), with its armed wing saying foreign hostages were among the dead, ahead of a planned visit to Israel by US Secretary of State Antony Blinken. ;

;Israeli forces thrust deeper into Gaza City - the Gaza Strip's main city - in their assault on Hamas, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Thursday, but the militant group resisted their drive with hit-and-run attacks from underground tunnels.

;

;The city in the north of the Gaza Strip has become the focus of attack for Israel, which has vowed to annihilate the Palestinian Islamist group's command structure and has told civilians to flee to the south.

;

;

;

;"Hamas has learned and prepared itself well," he said.

;

;Hamas and allied ;Islamic Jihad; fighters were emerging from tunnels to fire at tanks, then disappearing back into the network, residents said and videos from both groups showed.

;

;With international calls for a humanitarian pause in hostilities going unheeded, there was no letup in the suffering of Palestinian civilians, with ;UN experts; saying they were at "grave risk of genocide".

;

;Palestinian civilians ;have suffered shortages; of food, fuel, drinking water and medicine.

;

;"Water is being used as a weapon of war," said Juliette Touma, a spokesperson for the UN agency for Palestinian refugees UNRWA.

;

;In Khan Younis, in the south of the Gaza Strip, nine-year-old Rafif Abu Ziyada said she was ;drinking dirty water; and getting stomach pains and headaches.

;

;"There is no cooking gas, there is no water, we don't eat well. We are getting sick," she said. "There's garbage on the ground and the whole place is polluted."

;

;US Secretary of State Antony Blinken, before leaving for the Middle East on Thursday, said he would discuss concrete steps to minimise harm to civilians in Gaza, after saying earlier they were bearing the brunt of the conflict.

;

;Over a third of Gaza's 35 hospitals are not functioning, with many turned into impromptu refugee camps.

;

;"The situation is beyond catastrophic," said the charity Medical Aid for Palestinians, describing packed corridors and many medics who were themselves bereaved and homeless.

;

;"We remain convinced that the Palestinian people are at grave risk of genocide," seven UN special rapporteurs said in a statement in Geneva.

;

;"We demand a humanitarian ceasefire to ensure that aid reaches those who need it the most."

;

;The latest war in the ;decades-old conflict; began when Hamas fighters broke through the border on Oct. 7. Israel says they killed 1,400 people, mostly civilians, and took more than 200 hostages in the deadliest day of its 75-year-old history.

;

;Israel's ensuing bombardment of the small Palestinian enclave of 2.3 million people has killed at least 9,061 people, including 3,760 children and 2,326 women, according to Gaza health authorities.

;

;Israel says it has lost 18 soldiers and killed dozens of militants since ground operations were expanded on Friday.

;

;The ;Rafah crossing; from Gaza to Egypt was opened for limited evacuations for a second day under a Qatari-brokered deal between Israel, Egypt, Hamas and the United States, aimed at letting some foreign passport holders and their dependents, and some wounded Gazans, out of the enclave.

;

;Palestinian border official Wael Abu Mehsen said 400 foreign citizens would leave for Egypt via the Rafah crossing on Thursday, after some 320 on Wednesday.

;

;Dozens of critically injured Palestinians were to cross too. Israel asked foreign countries to send ;hospital ships; for them.

;

;"I want to pass. We are not animals," said Ghada el-Saka, an Egyptian at Rafah waiting to return home after visiting relatives. "We've seen death with our own eyes," she added, describing a strike near her siblings' house that had made her and her daughter live on the street.

;

;Suzan Beseiso, a US citizen with relatives in Gaza, said she was not excited to leave Gaza "because we have so many people that we love and care about".

;

;Though the United States and other Western nations have traditionally supported Israel, harrowing images of bodies in the rubble and ;hellish conditions; inside Gaza have triggered appeals for restraint and street protests around the world.

;

;Though Israel has told Gazans to go south, that part of the territory was not spared either. Three Palestinians died in tank shelling near the town of Khan Younis and an air strike killed five outside a UN school in Beach refugee camp, Gaza health officials said.

;

;In central Gaza, an air strike destroyed clusters of houses in the Bureij refugee camp, residents and Gaza officials said, with 15 bodies pulled from the rubble.

;

;"A massacre, a massacre," people cried as they gathered corpses in blankets.

;

;Israel's latest strikes have included the heavily populated area of Jabalia, set up as a refugee camp in 1948.

;

;Gaza's Hamas-run media office said at least 195 Palestinians were killed in the two hits on Tuesday and Wednesday, with 120 missing and at least 777 people hurt.

;

;Israel, which accuses Hamas of hiding behind civilians, said it killed two Hamas commanders in Jabalia.

;

;With Arab nations vocal in their outrage at Israel's actions, the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights said Israel's "disproportionate attacks" may constitute war crimes.

;

;Violence has also spread to the occupied West Bank, with Israeli raids touching off clashes with gunmen and people throwing stones.

;

;Climate change is accelerating and the world will cross the 1.5 degrees Celsius (2.7 Fahrenheit) warming threshold this decade, according to research published on Thursday that scientists said should raise alarms at this year's COP28 climate talks.

;

;Countries pledged in the 2015 Paris Agreement to hold global warming to within 1.5C above pre-industrial temperatures but the new paper by a team of scientists, including from NASA and Columbia University, adds to evidence suggesting that this goal is already out of reach.

;

;Most emissions scenarios under the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) envision the world breaching 1.5C during the 2030s.

;

;"The 1.5C limit is deader than a doornail," said study co-author James Hansen of Columbia University's Earth Institute who was among the first scientists to alert the world in the 1980s to the climate-warming impact of greenhouse gases.

;

;"The shortcoming of our scientific community is to not make clear to the political leaders what the situation is," he said.

;

;The world already has warmed by nearly 1.2C (2.2F) above preindustrial temperatures.

;

;The study has received mixed feedback from other climate scientists. Some ;questioned; its findings, with Michael Mann of the University of Pennsylvania saying in a blog post that they were "very much out of the mainstream".

;

;The new report comes after months of extreme weather shocks worldwide, from heatwaves in China to severe flooding in Libya, with 2023 set to be the ;warmest year; on record.

;

;Countries will gather later this month in Dubai for the annual UN climate summit to discuss global policy efforts to rein in greenhouse gas emissions.

;

;The study's findings, published in the journal ;Oxford Open Climate Change;, result from two factors.

;

;Scientists have underestimated how sensitive the Earth's climate is to rising carbon dioxide levels. The IPCC has given a best-guess estimate that the doubling of atmospheric carbon dioxide levels would yield global warming of around 3C (5.4F).

;

;A better understanding of ancient climate data - gleaned from sources such as ice cores and tree rings - has resulted in a higher estimate of around 4.8C (8.6F), the study said.

;

;So far, atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations have risen from around 280 parts per million (ppm) in the preindustrial era to about 417 ppm today.

;

;Another factor cited by the report relates to China's progress in cleaning up air pollution, caused mainly by sulphur dioxide spewed from coal plants, alongside global efforts to curb such emissions from shipping.

;

;;Cleaning the skies;, while bringing health benefits and saving lives, accelerates climate change. Aerosols scatter and reflect solar radiation.

;

;Pennsylvania's Mann took issue with the notion that models have underestimated climate sensitivity, as well as with the impact of declining sulphur dioxide emissions from shipping.

;

;Others said the study was in line with other recent research.

;

;"Everything is accelerating," said climate scientist Klaus Hubacek of the University of Gronigen.

;

;Earlier this week, research published in the journal Nature Climate Change ;suggested; the world would need to reach net zero emissions by 2034 for a 50% chance of containing warming to 1.5C - far sooner than the global goal of 2050.

;They all remain charged with second-degree murder and other counts in Tennessee state court in Shelby County.

;Mulroy's office did not say whether Mills would testify against the other defendants as part of the deal. Mills' defense attorney, Blake Ballin, did not respond to requests for comment on whether Mills planned to do so.

;

;Federal and state prosecutors have both recommended a sentence of 15 years in prison for Mills. District Judge Mark Norris of the Western District of Tennessee will decide the sentence at an upcoming hearing, Mulroy's office said.

;

;Police video showed the officers kicked, punched and pepper-sprayed Nichols and struck him with a baton.

;

;At one point, officers held his hands behind his back so another could punch him in the face, while at other times Nichols cried out for his mother, who lived nearby.

;

;Police at the scene alleged he was driving erratically and evaded arrest.

;

;The officers also face a federal civil suit filed by civil rights lawyer Ben Crump on behalf of the family.

;

;The other officers charged in the case are Demetrius Haley, Emmitt Martin III, Justin Smith and Tadarrius Bean.

;

;The Memphis Police Department fired two other officers involved in the incident, suspended three more, and a ninth retired while facing a recommendation for termination, according to city officials.

;

;In addition, four employees of the Memphis Fire Department were disciplined for failing to provide proper medical care for Nichols as he sat against a patrol car with his hands cuffed behind his back.
